title: To everyone in 'elo hell'
body:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunning%E2%80%93Kruger_effect

Maybe it will help you, especially applies to silvers and bronzes

replies.body: I think the charts of how many people were in each rank will drastically change resulting in more than 50% in bronze.

I've noticed that when I judge my performance in a game I tend to think of it like "did I succeed in what I attempted to do" rather than "could I have done more." I'm working on changing this, because I think that mindset is the difference between people who believe they're in elo hell and people who climb.
Exactly.  It's interesting this seems to be the mindset of people who are really highly ranked, coincidence?

As someone that was in gold last season and now placed in bronze, i can see what people are talking about being in elo hell. It truly is real. When your teams refuse to listen to your correct calls, and instead they throw the game over and over, yeah, it is frustrating, and yeah, it is elo hell.
As someone who worked his way up from Bronze 4 to Gold 3, Elo Hell is definitely real.

When I play and carry with plats and diamonds on 5s and 3s teams and we place those in plat usually and I had an average kda of 7/4/8 in placements with and against diamonds, then derank cause of one troll and 3 matches with an afk on my team and now am stuck playing with bronze players who got lucky and ranked up to mid silver but now go 0/5/0 in 5 mins in all 3 lanes if not worse then I think I have the right to call this "elo hell."

Yes I know, there is no such thing, the enemy team typically feeds and throws as often as my teammates do, but going even and constantly going up and down due to this BS won't get me anywhere until the ranks stabilize and all these idiots who were bronze last season derank back down I doubt I'll be able to carry these  heavy morons all on my own.

So yeah, elo hell doesn't really exist, not really a thing, but placements this year were complete and utter sh*t and just about everyone knows it, so atm there is an "elo hell" in some semblance of the term, we just have to wait until the really bad players derank back into their "hell" so the rest of us can return and carry ourselves back out like we always have to and have done every year in placements.

That sounds made up tbh.

Look one of my last games up then, where I was Rengar jungle, Kayle was 0/6/0, Gragas was 0/3/1, and my Morgana and vayne bot were 3/7 together in 5 mins.

Only reason we started to recover was cause I hit 6 and the enemy jungle Vi was a complete fool and I started to get my lanes back into the game, but by that point it's kind of too late and you're only chance is for the enemy to screw up a few times and pray yours actually listens to you, the only person not feeding, but that rarely stays true for long.

That's ONE game that stands out in your memory.  What about the hundreds of games before that?  You're going to have bad games, but you are also going to have really good ones.

Did you play perfectly?  Could you have done better?  Focus on what you can change, not what you can't.

Ugh, I'll never understand why people think pointing out the obvious will help anyone at all... and I doubt you looked at my history if you think the "hundreds" of games before that were any better, sure not usually THAT bad, but still very awful, with my own kda being one of the only good ones or at least respectable ones.

And seriously the only thing for me to improve atm is somehow getting my team to actually listen to me, and warding more.  I do not buy enough wards, especially in jungle, mainly cause you fall behind no matter what in jungle most the time even if you get fed, so buying wards just slips my mind while I try to keep up in items/levels, but even in those games where I do ward a ton and in good places, idiot teams who never listen will always be idiot teams who never listen.

There's like a reverse psychology aspect to games atm ya know, like I can win early-mid game for my team if they don't hardcore feed like that match I mentioned and actually quite a few more, but if I do so they are almost GUARANTEED to get arrogant and stop listening to my pings and directions and start goofing around and chasing kills, only getting themselves killed while I try to push down lanes and force objectives we can either get for free or win a fight for.  You need your team to be behind while you stay relevant or even fed so they see you as their only hope and listen to you.  Like seriously the only games I've managed to force my teams to finish out are ones like that, where say I get hella fed in top lane and start pressuring mid with my advantage to keep us even, but my bot lane and jungle feed horrendously putting us on the back heel, yet my team sees my kda and realizes "this guy who is still positive about winning is doing very well, maybe we should listen to him!"

But getting that happy medium is ridiculously hard on purpose, and it really only applies to the way the ranks are right now, with so many bronze baddies too far up in rank due to the awful placement system.  Eventually they'll all derank anyway and those of us who got bumped down will once again just carry ourselves back out, the never ending climb I usually give up on once I hit gold again and just focus on ranked team play cause it's more fun and always will be....

This has been posted before but it's a good reminder.

ELO Hell does not exist, it's just an excuse for bad players to continue to make the same mistakes and blame their teams and match-ups.

Some people make the best of each situation and learn from it, others just blame everyone else for their failures.

I make several mistakes that costs me the game. I'm bad at the game. Having said this, how do I stop people from face-checking the enemy jungle or lanes without wards despite pinging to be careful? To stop people from afking or spamming /surrender due to dying a few times? To tell them to target the adcs especially when they're fed but instead they keep hitting the tankiest person on the team? To group up instead of ant trailing into the team and dying? To tell the support that just because you're a jungler who bought sightstone, doesn't mean they get to not buy one?

You can't control what others do, only yourself.  You said you're bad at the game.  That means you can improve and you need to focus on making the best decisions and plays at that moment.  If you continue to improve and play well, you'll move up as you're ready to do so.

You'll have good and bad players on your team, but you can't determine their actions, only your own.

If ELO Hell exists, how do players get to Platinum, Diamond, Master and Challenger tiers?  Are they just luckier than you?  Do they not have feeders, AFKs and bad players for that level?

Luck, not getting stuck via placements, friends to duo with, and yes improvement. Considering how those players are a minority to the rest of the ranked players, ELO Hell exists. ELO Heaven doesn't mean a Hell doesn't exist.

Its a good thing i read that about McArthur Wheeler, i had just came upon the very same conclusion about lemon juice, but judging by the words "the mistaken belief", it does not work >:\... well back to the drawing board.

Always check gold income. If you're not one of the three lowest when you lost, you did fine, imo. Always think back to games that were curbstomps. Look at the statistics, look at what you built in what order. Think about what you did wrong. For example, earlier today, my map awareness was godawful, and it cost me my lane, and in the end, my game. Is it normally like this? No. If I were to put up a list of all my wins and losses, would it be close to 50/50? Probably.
Everyone in bronze needs to see this post

Still, one can't attribute all the complaints of an Elo hell to the Dunning–Kruger effect. The truth is that in League, to climb up the odds are stacked against you. In order to get promoted one needs to be better than the average player in his/her tier. However, that also means that one will be matched with worst players on his/her team or against better players on the enemy team because of his/her MMR. Eventually, it becomes even more and more difficult to win. But it is fair because everyone has to go through this.

Climbing up is not an easy task no matter how good you are, but that is how it is meant to be.
